--- title: "Data Summary and Visualization" subtitle: "STA 101 - Summer I 2022" author: "Raphael Morsomme" footer: "[sta101-suI22.github.io/website](https://sta101-suI22.github.io/website/)" logo: "images/logo.jpg" format: revealjs: theme: slides.scss multiplex: true transition: fade slide-number: true code-fold: false code-summary: "Show the code" code-link: true code-copy: true self-contained: true scrollable: true editor: visual execute: freeze: auto echo: true editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- # Welcome ## Announcements - If you're just joining the class, welcome! Go to the [course website](https://sta210-s22.github.io/website) and review content you've missed, read the syllabus, and complete the *Getting to know you* survey. - Drop/Add for Term 1 ends tomorrow. ## Franklin and Gilman have read the syllabus... [![](images/lec-3/frank_gil.jpeg){fig-alt="Picture of two of guinea pigs, Franklin (albino) and Gilman" width="800"}](https://rmorsomme.github.io/website/course-syllabus.html) ## Recap of last lecture ::: incremental - observations (row) and variables (column) - population parameters and sample statistics - statistical inference - sampling - four types of variables - experiments, observational studies and causal claims ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Breakdown of variables into their respective types.](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/variables-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='Types of variables are broken down into numerical (which can be discrete or continuous) and categorical (which can be ordinal or nominal).' width=80%} ::: ::: Source: [IMS](https://www.openintro.org/book/ims/) ## Outline - Visualization for numerical data - Summary for numerical data - Visualization for categorical data - Summary for categorical data - More visualizations > "The greatest value of a picture is when it forces us to notice what we never expected to see." --- John Tukey ## 7 Billion: Are You Typical? [National Geographic](https://youtu.be/4B2xOvKFFz4) . . . ::: {.callout-tip icon="false"} ## Group exercise - data summaries? 1. What variables are mentioned in the video? 2. What are their types? 3. How were they summarized and/or visualized? ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Visualization for numerical data ## US birth data ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} d_birth <- fivethirtyeight::US_births_1994_2003 ``` ::: There are 3,652 observations (rows) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} nrow(d_birth) # number of rows ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3652 ``` ::: ::: and 6 variables (columns) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ncol(d_birth) # number of columns ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 6 ``` ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} head(d_birth) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 x 6 year month date_of_month date day_of_week births 1 1994 1 1 1994-01-01 Sat 8096 2 1994 1 2 1994-01-02 Sun 7772 3 1994 1 3 1994-01-03 Mon 10142 4 1994 1 4 1994-01-04 Tues 11248 5 1994 1 5 1994-01-05 Wed 11053 6 1994 1 6 1994-01-06 Thurs 11406 ``` ::: ::: ## Histogram ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1|2"} ggplot(d_birth) + geom_histogram(aes(births)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## - Higher bars indicate where the data are relatively more common - More days with around 8,000 births or with around 12,500 births - Few days with less than 7,000 or more than 14,000 births. - Also few days with around 10,000 births We can change the number of bins to have a rougher or more detailed histogram. ## ::: panel-tabset ## bins = 10 ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_birth) + geom_histogram(aes(births), bins = 10) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## bins = 100 ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_birth) + geom_histogram(aes(births), bins = 100) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ::: ## Statistics as an art - describing a distribution {.smaller} It is always a good idea to make a histogram of continuous variables. To describe a distribution, we comment on - mode(s): unimodal, bimodal, multimodal - shape of each mode: flat, bell-shape, bounded - symmetry: symmetric, left skewed, right skewed - outliers: presence of extreme values - ... ::: callout-note Note that some distributions will not fit nicely in these categories. ::: ## Describing the US birth data The distribution of the daily number of births in the US is **bimodal** with each mode being **bell-shaped** and **symmetric**. We observe **no extreme value**. ## ::: {.callout-tip icon="false"} ## Group exercise - describing a distribution Exercises 5.10 ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
03:00
``` ::: ::: ## Scatterplots ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} d_car <- ggplot2::mpg head(d_car) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 x 11 manufacturer model displ year cyl trans drv cty hwy fl class 1 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 auto(l5) f 18 29 p compa~ 2 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 manual(m5) f 21 29 p compa~ 3 audi a4 2 2008 4 manual(m6) f 20 31 p compa~ 4 audi a4 2 2008 4 auto(av) f 21 30 p compa~ 5 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 auto(l5) f 16 26 p compa~ 6 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 manual(m5) f 18 26 p compa~ ``` ::: ::: We will look at the relation between engine size (`disp`) and fuel efficiency (`hwy`). ## ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1|2"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_point(aes(displ, hwy)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## Scatterplots are used to visualize the relation between two numerical variables. . . . ::: callout-note To add an additional variable to your visualization, you can use color or symbols. ::: ## ::: panel-tabset ## Colored points ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_point(aes(displ, hwy, col = drv)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## Symbols ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_point(aes(displ, hwy, shape = drv)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ::: # Summary for numerical data ## Measures of centrality - The **average**: $\bar{x} = \dfrac{x_1 + \dots + x_n}{n}$ - The **median**: the middle value . . . ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} mean(d_birth$births) # average ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 10876.82 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} median(d_birth$births) # median ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 11615 ``` ::: ::: ## Percentiles Percentiles are a generalization of the median. Since the median value is larger than 50% of the data and smaller than the rest it is called the 50th percentile. Similarly, the value that is larger than p% of the data and smaller than the rest is called the **p-th percentile**. . . . We will soon make use of the 25th and 75th percentiles. Later in the course, the 95th and 97.5th percentiles will also be useful. ## Measures of variation - **Variance**: average *squared* distance from the mean - **Standard deviation** (sd): square root of the variance (roughly speaking, the average distance to the mean) - Most (+- 95%) of the data is within 2 sd of the mean. - **Inter-quartile range** (IQR): distance between the 25th and the 75th percentiles. . . . ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} var(d_birth$births) # variance ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3454270 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sd(d_birth$births) # sd ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1858.567 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} IQR(d_birth$births) # iqr ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3429.75 ``` ::: ::: ## Robustness Real-world data often contain **extreme** values - measurement error, - typo - ... The average, median, variance, sd and iqr are not equally robust to the presence of extreme values. . . . Let us contaminate the birth data with a value of 1 billion... ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1|2"} x_uncontaminated <- d_birth$births x_contaminated <- c(x_uncontaminated, 1e9) ``` ::: . . . ...and compare the mean, median, variance, sd and iqr of these two variables ## ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(x_uncontaminated) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. 6443 8844 11615 10877 12274 14540 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} summary(x_contaminated) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. 6.443e+03 8.845e+03 1.162e+04 2.846e+05 1.228e+04 1.000e+09 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} var(x_uncontaminated); var(x_contaminated) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3454270 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2.737417e+14 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sd(x_uncontaminated); sd(x_contaminated) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1858.567 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 16545140 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} IQR(x_uncontaminated); IQR(x_contaminated) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3429.75 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3430 ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-warning ## Robustness of the median and the iqr While the **median and iqr are robust** to the presence of extreme values, the mean, the variance and the sd are not. ::: ## ::: {.callout-tip icon="false"} ## Group exercise - summary statistics Exercises 5.8, 5.11, 5.15 (replace part $c$ by *height of adults*) Note: Q1 is first the 25th percentile (larger than one *quarter* of the data), Q3 is the 75th percentile. ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
06:00
``` ::: ::: # Summary for categorical data ## Frequency table (1d) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} head(d_car) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 x 11 manufacturer model displ year cyl trans drv cty hwy fl class 1 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 auto(l5) f 18 29 p compa~ 2 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 manual(m5) f 21 29 p compa~ 3 audi a4 2 2008 4 manual(m6) f 20 31 p compa~ 4 audi a4 2 2008 4 auto(av) f 21 30 p compa~ 5 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 auto(l5) f 16 26 p compa~ 6 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 manual(m5) f 18 26 p compa~ ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} table(d_car$drv) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` 4 f r 103 106 25 ``` ::: ::: ## Contigency table (2d) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} table(d_car$class, d_car$drv) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` 4 f r 2seater 0 0 5 compact 12 35 0 midsize 3 38 0 minivan 0 11 0 pickup 33 0 0 subcompact 4 22 9 suv 51 0 11 ``` ::: ::: ## Proportion table (2d) ::: panel-tabset ## table proportion ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2|3"} table(d_car$class, d_car$drv) %>% prop.table() %>% round(2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` 4 f r 2seater 0.00 0.00 0.02 compact 0.05 0.15 0.00 midsize 0.01 0.16 0.00 minivan 0.00 0.05 0.00 pickup 0.14 0.00 0.00 subcompact 0.02 0.09 0.04 suv 0.22 0.00 0.05 ``` ::: ::: ## row proportion ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} table(d_car$class, d_car$drv) %>% prop.table(1) %>% round(2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` 4 f r 2seater 0.00 0.00 1.00 compact 0.26 0.74 0.00 midsize 0.07 0.93 0.00 minivan 0.00 1.00 0.00 pickup 1.00 0.00 0.00 subcompact 0.11 0.63 0.26 suv 0.82 0.00 0.18 ``` ::: ::: ## column proportion ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} table(d_car$class, d_car$drv) %>% prop.table(2) %>% round(2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-stdout} ``` 4 f r 2seater 0.00 0.00 0.20 compact 0.12 0.33 0.00 midsize 0.03 0.36 0.00 minivan 0.00 0.10 0.00 pickup 0.32 0.00 0.00 subcompact 0.04 0.21 0.36 suv 0.50 0.00 0.44 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## ::: {.callout-tip icon="false"} ## Group exercise - contigency and proportion table 1. What does the number $12$ represent in the contigency table? 2. What does the number $0.05$ (2nd row, 1st column) represent in the first proportion table? 3. What does the number $0.25$ (2nd row, 1st column) represent in the row proportion table? ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Visualization for categorical data ## Barplot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_bar(aes(drv)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## Advanced barplots ::: panel-tabset ## stacked ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_bar(aes(drv, fill = class)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## dodged ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_bar(aes(drv, fill = class), position = "dodge") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## standardized ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_bar(aes(drv, fill = class), position = "fill") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ::: ## ::: {.callout-tip icon="false"} ## Group exercise - pros and cons of barplots Exercise 4.5 ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
03:00
``` ::: ::: # Advanced visualizations ## Facetted histograms ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1|2,3|4"} d_birth_small <- filter(d_birth, year %in% c(1994, 1997, 2000, 2003)) ggplot(d_birth_small) + geom_histogram(aes(births)) + facet_grid(year~.) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## Mosaic plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(drv), fill = class)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: . . . ✅ Combines the strengths of the various barplots 🛑 Not in the tool box of every data scientist ## Boxplots [![from R4DS, Wickham and Grolemund](images/lec-3/EDA-boxplot.png)](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/index.html) ## - The thick line in the middle of the box indicates the median - The box stretches from the 25th percentile to the 75th percentile; it covers 50% of the data. - The length of the whiskers are at most 1.5 iqr - Any observation more than 1.5 iqr away from the box is labelled as an outlier. ::: callout-note ## Outliers Outliers have an extreme value. How to deal with an outlier depends on why the observation stands out. ::: ## ::: {.callout-tip icon="false"} ## Group exercise - types of associations Exercise 5.13 ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
02:00
``` ::: ::: ## ::: panel-tabset ## Boxplot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_birth) + geom_boxplot(aes(y = births)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## Side-by-side boxplots ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(d_birth) + geom_boxplot(aes(y=births, x=day_of_week)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-35-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ::: # Editing figures ## Figure title ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_point(aes(displ, hwy)) + labs(title = "Fuel consumption on the highway per engine size") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-36-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## Axis title ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="5,6"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_point(aes(displ, hwy)) + labs( title = "Fuel consumption on the highway per engine size", x = "Engine size (number of cylinders)", y = "Fuel efficiency on the highway (mpg)" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-37-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## ::: panel-tabset ## theme_bw ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="8"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_point(aes(displ, hwy)) + labs( title = "Fuel consumption on the highway per engine size", x = "Engine size (number of cylinders)", y = "Fuel efficiency on the highway (mpg)" ) + theme_bw() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## theme_classic ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="8"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_point(aes(displ, hwy)) + labs( title = "Fuel consumption on the highway per engine size", x = "Engine size (number of cylinders)", y = "Fuel efficiency on the highway (mpg)" ) + theme_classic() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-39-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ## theme_dark ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="8"} ggplot(d_car) + geom_point(aes(displ, hwy)) + labs( title = "Fuel consumption on the highway per engine size", x = "Engine size (number of cylinders)", y = "Fuel efficiency on the highway (mpg)" ) + theme_dark() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-3x_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-40-1.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ::: ## Editing tables {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3|4"} table(d_car$class, d_car$drv) %>% prop.table(1) %>% round(2) %>% kbl(caption = "Distribution of drive type per class of car") %>% kable_classic(full_width = FALSE, c("striped", "hover")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Distribution of drive type per class of car

2seater 0.00 0.00 1.00
compact 0.26 0.74 0.00
midsize 0.07 0.93 0.00
minivan 0.00 1.00 0.00
pickup 1.00 0.00 0.00
subcompact 0.11 0.63 0.26
suv 0.82 0.00 0.18
````` ::: ::: 📋 See [this vignette](https://haozhu233.github.io/kableExtra/awesome_table_in_html.html) for more details on editing tables # Effective communication ## Statistics as an art - figures ::: incremental - Have a purpose: is the figure necessary? - Pasimony: keep it simple and avoid distractions - Tell a story: provide context and interpret the figure - $\ge3$ variables as much as possible: color, facets, etc. - Edit your figure: title, axes, etc . . . 📋 See [R for Data Science - chapters 3 and 7](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-visualisation.html) for more on data visualization in R. ::: # Recap ## Recap ::: incremental - Histogram, scatterplot, boxplot - Average, median, variance, sd and IQR; robustness - Frequency, contigency and proportion tables - Barplot, mosaic plot - Effective communication: well-edited figures, $\ge3$ variables (symbols, colors, facets) - [R for Data Science - chapters 3 and 7](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-visualisation.html) ::: . . . > "The simple graph has brought more information to the data analyst's mind than any other device." --- John Tukey

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {

      // dispatch for htmlwidgets
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for reveal
    if (window.Reveal) {
      window.Reveal.addEventListener("slidechanged", function(event) {
        fireSlideChanged(event.previousSlide, event.currentSlide);
      });
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
